verdict.summary: Docker failed to set up iptables rules for container networking. Occurs when iptables is locked, rules conflict with existing firewall configurations, or iptables/nftables mismatch.

dead_ends.action: Flushing all iptables rules with iptables -F
dead_ends.why_fails: Deletes all firewall rules including security rules, potentially exposing the host to network attacks
Containers cannot reach the internet or each other; port publishing stops working entirely

workarounds.action: Restart the Docker daemon to recreate iptables chains
workarounds.how: sudo systemctl restart docker â€” Docker will re-create its iptables chains cleanly

workarounds.action: Switch Docker to nftables backend if the system uses nftables
workarounds.how: Check if system uses nftables: nft list ruleset. If so, ensure iptables points to iptables-nft: sudo update-alternatives --set iptables /usr/sbin/iptables-nft
workarounds.condition: when the system uses nftables but Docker expects iptables-legacy

leads_to.condition: when broken iptables rules prevent DNS traffic

preceded_by.condition: when network conflicts corrupt iptables state

frequently_confused_with.distinction: iptables failed is about firewall rule creation failing, while network bridge conflict is about IP address/subnet overlap between Docker and host networks
